title: 103_s1680
content: The "Smoke-Free Environment Act of 1993" establishes a uniform indoor air policy for public facilities regarding environmental tobacco smoke. It amends the Toxic Substances Control Act to include Title V, which defines the purpose and key terms related to this policy. The purpose of this title is to establish a uniform indoor air standard for public facilities with respect to environmental tobacco smoke. Definitions include environmental tobacco smoke, public facility, and responsible entity. The responsible entity for each public facility must adopt a uniform indoor air policy prohibiting environmental tobacco smoke emissions on the premises and near entrances, with clear notices posted. The responsible entity for each public facility must adopt a uniform indoor air policy prohibiting environmental tobacco smoke emissions on the premises and near entrances. An exception can be made for specially designated smoking areas within the facility if they meet specific ventilation requirements set by the Administrator. The responsible entity for a public facility can petition the Administrator for a waiver from compliance with indoor air policy prohibiting tobacco smoke emissions. The waiver, if granted, must protect nonsmokers to the maximum extent practicable and will be published in the Federal Register. The Administrator must publish each petition for a waiver and subsequent actions in the Federal Register. An annual report to Congress on all waivers granted in the previous year is also required. "SEC. 504. ENFORCEMENT." Penalties for non-compliance with section 503 include a civil penalty of up to $5,000 per day of violation. The court can allocate these penalties for projects aligned with the title's purpose. Actions to enforce section 503 can be initiated by aggrieved parties, government agencies, or the Administrator, with a 60-day notice requirement before legal action. An aggrieved person must give notice of violation at least 60 days before taking legal action under this section. Legal action can be taken in a district court where the defendant resides or does business to enforce section 503 and impose civil penalties. The court may award costs of litigation to a prevailing plaintiff in a final order under this section. SEC. 505 states that this title does not override any other laws protecting from health hazards of environmental tobacco smoke. SEC. 506 allows the Administrator to issue necessary regulations. Effective one year after enactment.
